review:
I played 5 minutes of this game and asked for a refund. I am sure the storyline gets better after you get invested in it, but the controls and some of the things that go on during the first few moments of the game just made me feel unattracted.
First of all, I will never understand why everyone in the village will be more attractive than your own character. For some reason farming games always make the main character look like the plainest kid in school. It would be nice to actually have an option to personalize your character more than skin color, gender and hair color... 
The controls were weird, I couldn't really tell how to target things to use tools, I just had to click at random and hope it hit the thing I was going for. The hoe tool was glitchy, the watering can I couldn't tell which plot was going to work on, I couldn't tell where the seeds I was planting was going to go... Just little things that from a veteran farming game person are a major oversight for general gameplay enjoyment.
I did not like that the natural items replenish anytime you leave the map. It made me feel like exploring and gathering the items wasn't even worth my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198978759359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1687276625}
review:
My. Word.

I am speechless.

This game is like if someone gives you a puzzle that makes a beautiful picture, but as you try to put the pieces together, it's hard to get the pieces to fit in each slots and you end up breaking them. You could probably still play with the puzzle pieces, but it's a mess and it's not fun.

This has so much potential, the art style is beautiful and it could've been much more. 

However the first half an hour I played is just me having question marks all over my face because I don't know what are things that can be interacted with or not. 

The control is janky as hell and you end up with always using your tools when you try to interact with the townsfolk. 

It's so hard to interact with anything, or anyone in that matter. When you enter a room you can still move wherever you want as you wait the screen to turn black to move you. 

When you use pillow outside, if you keep repeating it (happens when I tried to interacting with people and having the pillow as active tool) it glitches and transports you because the game still counted your movements prior to the sleeping animation.

Even interaction wise, the start of the scenario didn't make me feel welcomed. I've talked with few villagers and they just make me go 'ugh' and I just don't care enough for them.

The sound designs... I don't know if it's just me or anyone else felt the same but it was so, so, so grating and annoying that I had to turn the volume off. And this, I actually tried adjusting the volume in game and it didn't work! Even when I turned it to 0! I don't know anymore...

It was a shame because I really like the art style. I do. And I hope as more time is spent (looks at the 2017 release date...) ... This game will be truly finished. In a playable way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026004314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 633, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1686692767}
review:
There are much [i]much[/i] better games out there to buy for 25$ than this game. 

I'll start this by saying- I understand this game is EA, and has been since it's release in April 2017, with that said I originally played the game in June 2019 and it was working much better and had less issues. 
I got this game in June 2019 and I can't exactly remember the price but I think I grabbed for around 7-10$. The fact they are now charging 24.99$ USD for this broken hot mess is gross and the game is NOT worth that much right now.

When I originally played in 2019 I played 9 hours straight no issues. In 2023 I played over 1 hour and I've had issues left and right, having to quit and restart trying to change options and stuff. 
I have issues with the volume. I turned the music volume down to 25 and going into stores the music still blasts in my headset.

I stopped playing originally because I got bored and then decided to wait for updates, forgot about it then finally decided to replay it 5 years later since they did so many updates.... 
When I first started playing I was able to fully play with Xbox 360 controller. I have the same controller and can no longer play with controller? Because somehow using controller got broken in an update?

Fast forward to 2023 finally decided to check the game out, they did a complete overhaul town and area is completely different. Though now I can't do the tutorial at all tried 3 times, it freezes up and doesn't let me do anything. So I had to skip the tutorial. I get black screens every now and then when I try to transition to areas, I can fully say this is NOT a PC problem but issues with the game.

I noticed I have to sometimes click multiple times just to pick up stuff from the ground.
I get they're updating the game, and that's great but there needs to be much more work done.
I remember the game play and controls being so much better 5 years ago than it is now. The game looks prettier but that's about it so far. 

As it stands right now, wait to get the game, whether it's on sale or months from now when it's fully playable. The devs need to fix this a lot more before it's 100% playable and working again. I'll wait around some more since it's way too late to refund the game anyway and see how it progresses, but going from a working game, to completely revamping it and now it's buggy as heck isn't a good sign as of right now. I just hope I can come back and give this game a positive because it has some potential to be so much more.

review:
The game was quite a lot of fun in earlier incarnations. I played quite a bit of it during the initial early access, and had quite a bit of fun with it. It was a steadily developing farm sim, nothing groundbreaking within the genre... but it had charm and decent polish for an indie game. 

I stepped away to play other games and came back for the summer update. I'm not sure what happened, but the game is a mess. Controls are awkward; things like picking up items take multiple clicks to complete for no discernible reason. There are places on the map I was able to clip through (the stairs near the general store/mine). The graphics look worse than the earlier incarnations; the overall color of the game feels washed out as if they kicked the white point higher to make it look more retro. What was once a fun game has now become frustrating to the point that I can't bring myself to get past day 1. I cannot recommend this game in it's current state, and I hope there are major changes/fixes before the actual launch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037679503', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1807, 'last_played': 1644275373}
review:
Bought this game in December 2018 - that is four years ago now (for less than 10 Euros, mind you) for a game that is _still_ in EA. Since then the game has sparsely been updated, with the recent update transforming the game into a hot mess of all the unsquashed bugs Tyrion's cousin never got. The things that they _did_ work on, was taking everything out that made the game charming and a refreshing alternative to the already stale and overhyped other type(s) of this genre. Namely the fantasy elements - hence the reduction in the name of the game, formerly known as "Fantasy Farming: Orange Season". I am glad I only lost 10 eurones in the making of another Steam Disappointment (tm) and I wish good luck to everyone thinking this game of regurgitated content might be anywhere close to worth it's current price.

[Edit: Tumbled the words of the original game name, corrected. Also:]

I was checking with myself all day today, whether I had been too harsh in my negative review and I decided to research a bit more. Seems I was not too harsh at all, because checking out  the publisher via the Steam Databank made me aware of another abandonware game by them: "Wild Season - Episode 1" which has been abandoned way before work on this game here started, is _still_ available on Steam for a whopping 15 € despite the overwhelmingly negative reviews and is also not listed among the list of games on the publisher site here on Steam - one might wonder why (or actually, not). 

I strongly advise anyone to decide for themselves if they want to spend an insolent amount of 25 € for a game that is most likely going to be abandoned again soon, after being in EA for six years now and with an already dead, yet still available predecessor, that nets them money for no amount of work whatsoever.

review:
So far, I'm enjoying this game. If you like Stardew Valley then absolutely give this game a go. I first tried the demo that is available before committing to the paid version.

That being said, I have a few issues. I have played with both mouse and keyboard and Xbox controller. I feel like the game can be a bit unresponsive with a controller, in regards to selecting and completing actions with A. There have been no issues picking items up, but things like knocking on doors and especially interacting with the ground to hoe land/plant seeds/water plants usually needs 2 taps of A to register. My other issue is related. I have arthritis in my thumb on my right hand, and it would be much easier for me to play using a controller if there was at least the option to hold down the action button to repeatedly do an action. I can't play for very long because the need to repeatedly press the button with my thumb causes me pain. I realise I will be in a minority with the latter.

Overall though, very enjoyable and I look forward to what will happen with the game as it is further developed.

review:
As a big fan of both the Harvest Moon series and Stardew Valley I had hopes this would be of similar quality, but sadly I was deeply underwhelmed.

Not to say the game is inherently bad, it has potential for something amazing and I really do believe so, but as of its current state I wouldn't recommend buying it. I'm unsure if it'll ever get out of said-state since the last update was over a year ago, also with it being still in early access since 2017.

Didn't play much since it got mundane quite fast, but from what I've played I'll be listing some pros and cons.

Pros:
[list]
    [*]Appealing pixel style. Designs of the characters can be a hit or miss, but when it's good it's really good. Some portraits are inconsistent in terms of size but it's a minor issue.

    [*]Has some good ideas, like the companion system where an NPC joins your "party" as he/she follows you wherever you go and can be interacted with.

    [*]Lots of animals not only to take care of in your farm, but out in the wilderness too.

    [*]NPCs locations are shown on your map. This can also be seen as a con, as it takes you out of your immersion by not letting you discover their paths by yourself, but it can be helpful for finding specific ones for tasks.
[/list]

Cons: 
[list]
    [*]The areas (the townsquare, mountains, forest, etc) are [i] far [/i] too oversized, boring, empty and repetitive. Needs either massive map downscaling or environmental diversity/filling in. 

    [*]Knocking on doors animation takes ages, especially if you want to talk multiple times to the NPC.

    [*]The music can get VERY annoying as it's the same throughout the entire day.

    [*]Adding text that tells you you've already given the NPC a gift today to make it clearer as to why it wouldn't register would be nice.

    [*]Action/confirm and Use Item/Tool keys are the same mapping which can be confusing, [i] especially [/i] with the items and tools being in two separate bars which means you can accidentally consume something when you want to use a tool, because again, different bars meaning equipping two things at once with having a single button for both of them, not very smart design.
[/list]

You can take this with a grain of salt as again, it's still under development and many things can and probably will change, which is what I'm hoping for.

review:
I know my play time is short. I tried the game out, saw some promise, and decided to wait until it had a bit more time to implement features. That was March 2020. The last update of any note to this game was August 2020. The developer claims otherwise, but this project seems to be abandoned.

Do not purchase until (or if) regular updates and a road map become a thing. In its current state, Orange Season is just trying to grab some quick and easy money from people eager for more life sim/farming sim games.

UPDATE: As of December 2021, the "developer" is making updates again. I say "developer" because now it's not even the original programmer working on the game, but other programmers who were allegedly on the first team for the game. Who owns the IP then? Major red flags.

Second, in the December update, the new devs promised monthly updates. They then failed to get the February 2022 update out in February. So they made it...a month? More red flags aplenty.

This whole project screams failure at best, scam at worst. Stay far, far away.

review:
I'm honestly not sure where I land with this game. While I think it stands on its own very well and it's a perfectly enjoyable time-sink of a game, I also find myself increasingly frustrated with its mechanics and I don't know if that's due to it being early access or if I just fundamentally don't enjoy the choices they've taken with this game. 

Comparing it to Stardew Valley is almost unavoidable due to the similarities, which I think unfortunately highlights the glaring problems with Fantasy Farming. You're less constrained by the hours in the day, but you burn energy constantly with every single thing you do. And replenishing energy in any useful way costs thousands of dollars. Even sleeping for the night doesn't fully heal you. Money isn't terribly difficult to come by at least, but useful materials are.

Overall, I recommend it because at the end of the day, if you just want to play a farming sim, you'll probably have fun with it. But if you have anything else to compare it to, like Stardew, you may find it lacking. If there was a "Meh" option I would choose it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198145741858', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1607, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1679082486}
review:
It isn't hard for me to love a classic farming simulation game - nice visuals, good music, and simple gameplay is all I need to kill hours of my time. If you're a classic Harvest Moon fan, then this game starts out similarly to the original game - you're given a farm and a dog, except this time you scavenge around for starting tools. However, before I get into how fun this game is, I want to point out a few things that bug me (even though the game is still in development) that borderline deter me from playing the game. Immersion in terms of NPC interaction and dialogue is pretty awkward and hard to understand when you try to see the big picture of town fluency. It feels a little forced at times. The only other tedious thing is mining, which costs way too much stamina because you're digging soil trying to find stairs as well as hammering mine-able objects. Assuming the stairs don't spawn where an object is spawned on the floor, you have to spend time digging before mining anything because you might forget and dig in a useless area. By the end of your trip, you barely make any progress in comparison to how much stamina and time is consumed for the act. The final, very small complaint that I have is that when you have seeds in your hotbar/inventory, the only way that you'd find out their season and their growth time is if you go back to the store and check it out again. (I think the magnifying glass may be used for this also? I haven't tried that out yet but I am a forgetful person and I tend to have to go back and check the store).

 I understand that some of these elements may change drastically by the end of Early Access, so take all of these things with a grain of salt. If anything could be suggested just for fun, I think a romance option for Billy would be funny and interesting since he's so bad at farming and he has an eye on your farm as your unfortunately ignorant rival.

I can't convey how easy to navigate and how useful the pause menu is. There's so much information at your fingertips and it keeps track of a BUNCH of little things for those that are interested in those beautiful statistics. Speaking of statistics, not only is the pause menu useful, but pretty much every other menu that paints profit margins for you and is visually appealing on top of all that. Once you get a basic understanding of the game, you don't have to look anything up outside of it nor do you have to take very many notes (for those that min/max the game or just get really, really into it like I do!) The character designs are unique and cute, but Bonnie makes me nervous. There's plenty of work to be done throughout the game as a farmer and yet it doesn't make me feel as though I'm rushing to the next project constantly due to seasonal constraint; it's a fluent and satisfying game so far. Even if the mining kills me. Wonderful game, would recommend to others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045419392', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1574, 'last_played': 1623636663}
review:
So I will say that I understand that this is Early Access and things can change. As far as the marriage candidates go, I hope they do.

For the most part, I'm really enjoying this game. I like the exploration and the interactions. I like all the different animals. I really like the foundation and some of the ideas this game has implemented. I wish some things were more obvious to the user (like why my mushrooms aren't growing in the caves), but I also foresee this changing since it's Early Access. 

And for the record, I do recommend the game to others, purely because there is so much potential. Especially *given* that it's Early Access. And understand, that the romanceable characters are like the icing on the cake. The cake can still be delicious without it (sometimes you don't even need icing) -- but really good icing can change the entire flavor and make it that much better.

Which is exactly why I'm frustrated by it. 

For a game that boasts many marriage candidates (for the record, 5 men and 5 women isn't a lot, it's standard), I have a pretty big bone to pick with the ones they offer. 3/5 guys have a very similar hairstyle. Blondie has the most grating personality ever. Lucas has by far the most interesting design, but he has the personality of a wet noodle. The characters I'd love to romance -- like Gabriel or Duke, or even Billy aren't romanceable. Yumiko is a dime too. They are all non-marriage candidates. :( So I was like, okay, totally, I'll go for one of the ladies. But I feel like their designs are pretty similar too (3/5 with the same jaw and they all have long ass hair). I don't mind most of their personalities, but I the game devs are trying too hard to make them "realistic." It's okay to give them diverse personalities and lines -- in fact, I like the basis of this idea. But you also have to balance that notion with the fact that we are playing a game to have *fun* and escape reality. And hey, I wouldn't have an issue with it if any of the characters I was interested in were romanceable. But they aren't.

I hope that changes in the future. I would be so stinking excited to romance Gabriel. (And if they already announced more and I missed it, then I apologize and you can ignore this gripe).

Also, this is not aimed at these specific devs or designers, but just this genre in general. I'd like more masc-women. And more prettyboy men. Give us a butch-lady with short cropped hair and a smirk and a pretty-boy without facial hair. And anybody who says Benjamin looks like he has a ponytail in his sprite -- it's not obvious in his portrait, and he's not a prettyboy so it's a moot point. Something something Gabriel.

OKAY. All that aside, I still think this is a great game. And honestly if my biggest issue is the lack of pretty boys, they aren't doing a bad job. I will definitely continue to play regardless, and I think if you enjoy Harvest Moon/SoS/Stardew you will enjoy this game. :)
developer_response: Everyone within reasonable age is going to be romanceable eventually. We're just starting with 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198819529192', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 3099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2875, 'last_played': 1694280469}
review:
There's a lot of great content here and the game doesn't feel unpolished or unfinished for a substantial period of time into gameplay. It's enough like Stardew Valley that it could be its sequel, so I'd say that makes it a solid addition to my farm sim library. I am really enjoying it and look forward to more updates.

It also has features that make gameplay easier and more forgiving than Stardew Valley:

A pillow tool that you can use to take a nap anywhere and replenish your stamina - in-game clock speeds up to simulate the fast passing of time, making this tool also useful for when you are waiting for a particular business to open their doors. When you DO run out of stamina you will take an immediate and automatic nap. Also if you stay up very late you will just have less energy the next day to start off with. 

I also like how you have a separate toolbar for your tools and items, so you can never lose or misplace your tools since they are permanently attached to you (except for when you take them in for an upgrade at the blacksmith's, of course). 

I also love how if you reach the last bit of your stamina your farmer will very noticeably have a dizzy moment. Playing Stardew Valley I remember being so into gameplay that I wouldn't even notice the critical stamina warning sometimes until it was too late.

The game also enables the easy moving of buildings. So if you don't like where you put a barn/coop you can move it without hassle or having to pay any fees to have it moved.

Another great feature is that if you feel like you need a break from caring for all your animals you don't have to sell them, but can have the vet take care of them for free until you want them back - you just don't get any of their produce during that time (eggs, milk, wool, etc).

On a more personal note I also think that there are more villager characters I find likeable/interesting in Orange Season than in Stardew Valley. There was just something about the Stardew Valley characters that made them feel mostly more bland and uninteresting. So I'm grateful that these characters seem to have a more standout quality to them.

Features I would like to see added and bugs I would like to see fixed:

I'd like to be able to transfer animals to the coop/barn of my choosing via a roster in the coops/barns.

I'd like it if a character actually tells you that you have to use the hoe to find stairs to levels where the silver and gold ore are since it was some time into the game before I read the sign via a click and was like "Ohhhh, so that's where you get those."

I'd like to see a headlamp tool added for use in the night when the mine gets dark and its harder to make out which ore is which.

The items bar shows the number 2 when I really have 10.

I can't access Cindy's furniture for sale after she gives me the opportunity that one time to buy some (and I did). I think it's a bug.

I have experienced some wonkiness with doorways occasionally where the 'inside now' doesn't trigger and I have to go out and go back in (happens when I try to enter just as an NPC is). I also had a similar experience when I was 'hanging out' and tried to go into the spa.

Occasionally the game will freeze when I try to go to the festival area on a festival day (maybe it's because I was on horseback?).

Since the horse will wander a bit like a real horse likely would after you dismount, I would like the see the addition of hitching posts in some convenient and commonly frequented spots.

review:
Esse jogo, MEU DEUS. Que jogo perfeito.
  
  O que falar sobre Orange Season?! Se você jogou e gostou de stardew valley ou harvest moon, esse jogo é pra você. O jogo contem mecânicas simples de comprar sementes, planta-las, regar elas todo dia, coletar e vender. Além disso você pode explorar todo o mapa para coletar itens, desde as montanhas até a PRAIA.
  
  O jogo também contém uma mecânica de mineração em andares, igual a de stardew valley(Orange Season se baseou muito nesse jogo).

  Os NPCs são incríveis, cada um com sua característica e persoalidade, parece que são pessoas reais mesmo. Esse foi um dos únicos jogos que me fez sentir dentro dele. O jogo contém sistema de amizade e de namoro, e futuramente casameto.

  Em relação aos bugs, nunca vi nenhum. 
  
  UM AVISO NO JOGO: se você tiver comprado alguma coisa na loja e você tiver com seu inventario cheio, o vendedor não vai roubar seu item, ele vai colocar na sua caixa de correio :)

  Em geral eu dou uma nota 9.5~10, o jogo é muito bom, porém falta coisas básicas e grande coisas para as atualizações futuras. Outra coisa também, podia ser os criadores criarem um server no discord para os testers fazerem suas sugestões e relatarem bugs(se existir um, por favor me avisem no comentário dessa análise).

review:
It's a really bad version of Stardew Valley honestly. There are some quests that you can't even complete because the game mechanics are bad. For instance the Mayor gives you a quest to clear all the weeds from the town but it seems like a LOT of people have issues finding the last weed, and that is because it is mysteriously hidden behind a tree or a house and the locations are completely random on where they pop up. It wouldn't be such a big deal if the larger objects that you walk behind like trees would become semi transparent when you walk behind them so you can actually see what is behind them, rather than just randomly running around clicking behind things hoping that you MIGHT find it. That is just a bad and poorly thought out game mechanic and since there are several threads that are kind of old and it still hasn't been addressed by the devs, tells me that they really don't care about addressing bad game mechanics in their game.

The rest of the game mechanics such as the point and click finger are also very clunky and just feels wrong, you basically use it for everything in the game.  The map provided that you can use is not very accurate, the crafting menu is horrible and almost non existent, You can have chickens and eggs, but  you can't make items from the eggs, unless you go into town and use a camp fire, despite the fact that you have a house with a storage system. You can apparently race your chickens though which is just weird. Bottom line is if you are looking for a game similar to Stardew Valley, don't get this one. While it seems like almost a complete rip off of Stardew, it failed on so many levels that could have made it a decent and cute game.
My suggestion to the devs of this game, is to please work on your games mechanics and how the players interact with quests and other things in their world such as their farm. As the game stands it feels more like a free Facebook farming game rather than an actual farming simulator like it is trying to be. Also maybe listen to the feedback of the people who are trying to play the game? If you ignore the very base of the people you are trying to get to play this game, then your game won't get very far.

review:
Edit:  This review is of the old version of the game with the original developer.  I can't comment on the new version as I haven't played it.

TL;DR Fun and chill game where you occasionally get to race chickens or throw tomatoes at the townspeople.

A peaceful and delightful farming sim that offers a similar experience to other games but also much unique content.  In particular the inventory system is really functional and well designed.  The character development gets going after a while and the town's stories become increasingly entangled.   Also you can rest or save the game whenever you want and there is an NPC who babysits your animals if you're bored of taking care of them.  There are many fun festivals with a Brazilian cultural theme.  As well there is at least some diversity in the characters, much more so than in Stardew Valley.   The music is pleasing and overall atmosphere is simple, bright and colorful.  If you buy things when your inventory is full they get sent to your mailbox, which is convenient.  There probably isn't hundreds of hours of content but there is more than enough to justify the low asking price.  New updates are still being added and it is clear that player feedback is taken strongly into consideration.

review:
Should be a neutral review, but that's not an option, and something very negative happened, that's the reason for the negative review. 

I came to this game looking for a Stardew Valley-type of game and it delivers on that. It offers fairly similar mechanics and is fun to play.  I haven't come across any combat, but these games don't fare that well with combat anyway, so I don't mind.

Progression is sometimes a little vague, some of the essential tools are hidden in the most distant places. I prefer a system in which you can decide your own profession, but here, to get the fishing rod you have to cozy up to (bribe, befriend) a guy first. Upgrading your tools is vague, because the option suddenly appears. I would prefer this to be clear. But those are tiny things to complain about. 

It has the best inventory management system I have come across, because the game does it for you. You don't have to build storage at all, which is a smart decision, no one likes to organize their stuff. I really appreciate this. 

There are two health bars that act fairly similarly, I suppose since they have a doctor, at some point illnesses come into the game. I think one would have done just as well.

The reason why this is a negative review: My computer crashed on me and then my only save file was lost. So 6 hrs of progress gone. I have no problem managing my own saves, if I have reason to believe that stuff like that can happen, but I wasn't expecting this. Maybe putting a warning note in the game would help people to create several safe files.

If they solve this, this is a great game, I would wait for them to solve these issues first though. I am not going to start another run just yet. Maybe later.

English Version:
I began playing Orange Season illegally, after few month I had enough money to buy it and give some money to the one creating this game!! The game is'nt finished today but is playable for a year ingame for now! This game is in the same family as Stardew Valley, Graveyard Keeper, obviously with some differences. 
My favorite part of Orange Season is that you have to work with all your tool to improve it : you can't just neglect chopping stump and log and buy the best axe later when you're rich, each tool has an experience bar which has to be maxed to allow the upgrade!! 
Foraging is your best source of money early game, you will spend most of your time walking and searching fruits to earn some $$. I ended thinking about every possible path to choose which one is the more efficient. No violence and fight, no monster to kill when you're mining, it's a very peaceful game!
The game is updated regularly, and most bugs are fixed few days after update.

Le jeu est clairement dans la même lignée que Stardew Valley, Graveyard Keeper... Avec évidemment quelques différences!
Dans Orange Season, vous êtes obligé d'utiliser tous vos outils si vous voulez les upgrader, pas moyen d'économiser et d'acheter la meilleure hache, chaque outil a une barre d'XP que vous devez maxer si vous voulez acheter l'amélioration, perso c'est une contrainte que j'adore . 
Le glanage/ramassage d'items occupe la majorité de vos journées, surtout en début de partie, ce qui permet d'optimiser et de trouver le meilleur chemin pour un ratio items/temps optimal! 
Zero violence dans ce jeu: pas de combat, pas de monstres à tuer pendant que vous minez!
Le jeu est mis à jour régulièrement (quelques mois), et la majorité des bugs corrigés en moins d'une semaine après la MAJ.

review:
I played 35 hours of this game in the last 5 days. I'm hooked.

There's a severe lack of guides and information on some of the game's aspects but the Developer and the small but loyal community are quick to respond to players' inquiries which is nice to see. There's also a lot of carry-over knowledge for people like me who have played a lot of farming games.

Hopefully new art gets put into the game soon. The lack of portraits on some characters is a bit disorienting and ruins the immersion. 

Music is great and simple. Art style is nice and pleasing. Story is there but needs to be expounded on. The dating aspect is also begging to be updated as, from what the Wiki provides, each candidate only has one romantic heart-event. 

Anyway, so far I love this game a lot. It reminds me of some of Harvest Moon's old games in that it's simple, grindy, but also satisfying and addictive. 

I've played some SDV and the 3DS Story of Seasons games, and for what it's worth, Orange Season has some aspects to it that it does better than both franchises. It has a wild animal taming system much like the 3DS Story of Season games but you can take the animals back to your farm eventually which is exciting and new. It's mining is a lot more interactive than the 'hit here to collect' mining in Story of Seasons games, but it's also not as complex as Stardew Valley's as there is no combat in the game. 

Some things I wish would get added in the future:
1. More and better heart events akin to HM/SOS games where each stage of the heart progress unlocks and event.
2. Guides. I had to do a lot of discussion-digging here on Steam to find some things out for myself. I also quickly learned that some features didn't make it through the updates and were then obsolete which made it even more frustrating.
3. As I said, I'd really like for more art to be in-game. It'd be nice for the portraits to have different emotive versions to fit the dialogues. 
4. More domesticated animals. I really like the concept of breeding chickens until you get the perfect one, I just wish that the other animals get their chance to shine too as right now, they don't offer much interaction.
5. Quality meter on both crops and produce. The seed-maker is really 'meh'. In the farming games of recent, it's mainly used as a way to pass crop quality down until you get the perfect crop; without the quality meter on crops, it's really just for a little price discount. I'd also like to see a quality system on milk and eggs as at the moment, I don't think befriending your animals does much if anything at all. 

The Developer seems to be really hard-working and I wish them all the best. This game has a bright future and could be amazing; but for now, it's just good.

review:

The new company spent from December 2021 to December 2022 to do a single update, porting this to another engine, only for the game to be unplayable. Not just a few annoying bugs, the game right now it's a really bad demo. 

You start a new save and choose your character, and it can or can't look like what you chose in game. It depends, you can restart a few times and maybe it'll end up working. World will freeze and only flow when you have the menu open. If you manage to not get stuck at some point of the map and do not get the freezing bug, you roam around the world with characters  acting like they already know and like you, and 0 indications as of what to do. 

This review is now negative because I can't recommend a game that as of today it's not even playable. Sadly, I don't think this project is going to ever be complete in any satisfactory way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198426973930', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1050, 'last_played': 1606513894}
review:
I've been a diehard Stardew Valley fan for years, but after  countless hours playing it I was looking for something new. I stumbled across this game and dare I say it, I love it MORE than Stardew. The character interactions are AMAZING. Every character has a different storyline to follow and their comments change almost every day which keeps things really interesting. You can also "hang out" with characters and compete with them during festivals which is so much fun! The map in this game is huge and allows for tons of exploration. There are many "secret places" hidden around and they take a long time to find, so you'll never be bored! Another thing I love about this game is the variety of animals offered to purchase. You can get the normal cows, chicken, and horse, but you also can get ducks, yacks, and mountain goats. You can also ride your cow, yacks, and mountain goats in addition to your horse which is awesome! The farming in this game is equal to that of STV and there is mining and fishing. 

Overall, I LOVE this game and can't wait to see how it continues to progress.

author: {'steamid': '76561198238482240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 5650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1657, 'last_played': 1710603755}
review:
[h1][i]Análise mais recente de 2/12/2022:[/i][/h1]
Ok, eu estava 1000% hypada pra esse jogo, já que ele estava sendo completamente refeito em uma nova engine com promessas de novas mecânicas e várias melhorias (A antiga engine era o RPG Maker, que limita muito o desenvolvedor que queira fazer algo diferente de um j-rpg classicão).

O novo mapa é realmente lindo, mas está com milhares de erros de mapeamento e eu estou esperando abrirem uma thread de bugs pra postar tudo lá. De resto honestamente pra mim ficou pior, o que é uma pena, por que eu [b]realmente[/b] estava animada com essa atualização. 
Deixa eu listar algumas coisas:

🔹 Nós já sabíamos que a história seria toda refeita, mas essa nova versão [b]não possui sequer a introdução[/b]. Ou não possui, ou tem algum problema sério com a configuração de intro na tela de criação de personagem;
🔹 Simples animações de caminhar dos personagens muitas vezes não funcionam e o jogador se depara com [b]npcs deslizando pela rua[/b];
🔹 Transições de um mapa pra outro levam o jogador pra locais que não tem nada a ver (como entrar no galinheiro e aparecer na entrada da fazenda, por exemplo).
🔹 Erros de mapeamento que permitem que o jogador atravesse objetos que deviam ser sólidos e várias paredes invisíveis que não fazem sentido.
🔹 Se você tem um gamepad tem uma grande chance de que ele não funcione mais, assim como foi comigo e vários outros usuários (eu resolvi isso com um emulador de gamepad);
🔹 Consegui usar o botão de ação pra abrir um diálogo com um npc, mas só dá pra fechar com o botão configurado em "voltar" e não com o próprio botão de ação como antes;
🔹 Tudo parece estar pesadamente voltado pra jogar com teclado e mouse, a questão de acessibilidade e "qualidade de vida" está péssima.

Assim que eu soube que trocaram de engine pra Unity eu fiquei com sentimentos mistos. A Unity é definitivamente uma das engines líderes de mercado, mas em compensação o ambiente 2d dela é falso, não passa de um ambiente 3d simulando 2d. Eu aposto que na Godot Engine os desenvolvedores teriam conseguido fazer [b]muito mais[/b] nessa mesma quantidade de tempo, mas deixa isso quieto por que cada um usa a engine que quiser e eu não tenho nada a ver com isso hahaha.

Enfim, [b]Orange Season[/b], não fica triste, eu ainda te amo e vou sempre te dar uma chance, mas isso foi uma baita quebra de expectativa. Ainda assim vou continuar acompanhando o desenvolvimento e torcendo pra que os devs cheguem no ponto que eles planejaram pra esse jogo. Sigam firmes. 💪

[i]Análise original em 14/02/2020:[/i]

Vou tentar ser justa por ser um título em Early Access! Eu gostei do jogo, os gráficos melhoraram muito com o passar do tempo e já deu pra ver um avanço comparando a demo com a versão atual. O menu com o caderno me deixou apaixonada, fiquei um tempão abrindo e fechando ele só pra ver aquela animação linda hahaha. Os NPCs têm sua personalidade, só ainda não foi tanto explorada quanto poderia, mas, acima de tudo, o que eu mais senti falta foi de um objetivo grandioso principal. Algo acima dos pequenos objetivos e que eu precisaria de uns dois anos pra alcançar, tipo o que temos em HM: The tale of two towns ou outros do mesmo gênero. O Monomito é uma excelente referência de estrutura para criação de histórias, humildemente recomendo. No mais, estou acompanhando o trabalho de vocês devs e ansiosa pra ver o que mais vocês trarão ao jogo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198071673040', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 923, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1626987056}
review:
Bom vamos lá sobre minha avaliação do Fantasy Farming: Orange Season.

O jogo se trata de um game sobre administração de uma fazenda, no mesmo Pick de Harvest Moon.
Nosso protagonista pode ser modificado(Poucas Modificações entre cor de pele e etc).
Escolhemos nosso nick dentro do game, o nome do nosso cachorro e o nome da nossa fazenda. 
O Jogo a principio de Game é muito divertido, pelo fato de sempre estarmos procurando lugares novos, npc e etc.
Uma coisa que eu gostei muito desse ínicio é que o game não te entrega logo as ferramentas de cara(Procura não pra vc ver se te dão dicas kkk)
O Mapa é GIGANTE , eu dificilmente conseguia fazer tudo a pé, depois que comprei um cavalo consegui me locomover mais rapido!!
Sistema de plantação é muito bom(Uma coisa que nunca vi em algum game é que o cachorro faz xixi em algumas plantas e elas ficam como se fossem regadas... isso é uma coisa que me deixou maravilhado)
Temos update nas ferramentas principais do game. Sendo feita no ferreiro da cidade. Temos update de Cobre,Prata e Ouro por enquanto(No regador é diferente. O primeiro Update é prata, Rubi e esmeralda).

Uma coisa que me deixou meio triste foi a falta de eventos. Temos um no primeiro mês e 1 no segundo... Parando por ai. Outono e Inverno não existem eventos (Creio que ao passar das atualizações, irão adicionar).

O Jogo tem muita pegada e referência ao Brasil, como o Saci, ou o Curupira(Tendo quest com ele)
Me alegra o coração do jogo ter sido feito inicialmente por um Brasileiro, isso demonstra que tambem podemos entrar nesse mercado de games.

Os Npc's do game são muito fofos. Cada um com sua personalidades únicas ,cada um tem seus problemas e histórias.

O jogo está muito bom para a fase de desenvolvimento que está, mas como nem tudo é perfeito, eu vou listar algumas coisas que não curti muito.


Estou no inverno do Primeiro Ano, e o jogo meio que está se tornando enjoativo, já que estou a 1 semana com 40000 mil de gold sem ter noção com oque gastar. Já tenho a maioria dos updates e é isso.

Chega uma hora que fica muito repetitivo ter que fazer a rota da montanha todo dia pra pegar loot. 

Não sei se precisa liberar algo , mas só consegui fazer 1 update da casa, pelo fato do npc falar que não pode fazer mais updates.

A Pesca é Legal, com uma proposta bacana e diferentes de outros jogos semelhantes. Mas chega a ser enjoativo. Precisamos está esperando o peixe passar por cima da isca, e isso torna meio repetitivo saca, sem nenhum desafio . talvez uma dificuldade com uma recompensa melhor seria o ideal.

review:
First off - yes, this game is like other games in the same genre (ie: Stardew Valley, Harvest Moon) and, yes, that is exactly why I bought it. I love those types of games but once you make your fifth farm... well, there is only so much to do, isn't there? 
So, when I saw this game for sale at a modest price and good reviews, I decided to give it a shot. Am I happy? Yes. Could I be happier? Yes. 
The thing is, this game is still in development and you can tell. Pictures on NPCs don't show up on the text boxes, sometimes the FPS drops down to "is the game about to die" (fixed by a quick reboot of the game), and other little things. But, I am okay playing am game with those things happening as long as I think it is worth it. And, in this case, I do.
I have to assume one or both of two things is true: 1) the developer is a longtime player of games in this genre 2) the developer has been reading through complaints and wishes for other games in this genre. Why do I think that? Well, here are a couple examples:
a) When I went to buy seeds (which, as far as I can tell, you can buy on any day), I was given the information about the seed and plants whenever I had them selected. How much they cost, how much they sell for, how long they grow, how many days in-between growths. All right there. How many times have I wished for that info at that moment in other games??? It was awesome. 
b) The map shows people WHERE THEY ARE. Not where they live. Where they are at that moment. Trying to hunt someone down? Never fear! If you can recognize their little face, you can stalk them. [side note: a legend of who is who would be great because I have a hard time with real human faces, not to mention little animated ones]
c) YOU can MOVE BUILDINGS. I am a bit of a designer, and so moving buildings is a big deal to me. I don't even have to wander, for example *coughcough*, up into the mountains and use an NPC to do it only to realize that there is a piece of plowed land in the way. 
d) For me, it really harkens back to the good-old memories of a certain GameBoy Advance game. A little grindy, a little gritty, but still an adventure. 
So, would I buy it again? Yes. Do I want to see changes? Yes. Should you buy it? If you are willing to say "ah yeah, I guess that feature isn't ready yet but OMG look at my crops and chickies!!!"

Things that might make things better:
Character Clothes Customization (ie: pants for the ladies - who farms in a skirt?)
Instead of "pet" name, maybe just go ahead and say dog?
Transparent Trees (would like to see what is behind those dang things)
Names of people & places when you hover over them on the map

review:
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

[i]Fantasy Farming: Orange Season[/i] is an indie farming-simulation RPG much in the same spirit of the [i]Harvest Moon[/i] games and also [i]Stardew Valley.[/i] Similarities would certainly group these games together in many of the same categories of comparison, whereas the differences would allow the player to enjoy each for its own game.

Similar in style, art direction, and gameplay, these games all offer a start-up farm after a quick introductory story. I haven't played [i]Harvest Moon[/i] Since the Wii and it's been about 2 years since I fiddled around in [i]Stardew Valley,[/i] so my recollection of those games are only from memory. Thus I am not going to be offering any kind of significant comparison, but rather talk about this game alone. In addition, Please keep in mind that 8 hours is a really (and I mean, reeeeally) short time period to offer proper judgement of a game of this type, so this is a mere first-impressions review.

[h1]Gameplay/Game Content[/h1]
So you want to know what you can do in this game? To lay it out in numbers, there are 25 other people to meet and to interact with in town, 14 different types of animals to own, 43 areas to explore (the buildings in town all count separately), 50 cooking recipes, 271 different items you can ship to sell, and currently 25 available tasks as of right now in Early Access. The recipes list is being developed and you cannot look at it from your menu yet. And I believe that there will be significant addenda to the actual tasks/quests, because 25 really seems like a fairly low number. (Although depending on how long you are planning to spend playing the game, I have completed 9/25 tasks so far in my time playing.)

As expected, you are going to be cleaning off areas of your farm, farming vegetables, fruits, etc. You will have to take good care to water your plants otherwise you will lose part of your crop. Before your first crops are harvested, you can explore around the local areas to forage for items to sell, so that you are able to make some money. Exploring also opens your own abilities because several of the essential farming tools are only found scattered around the map, and having them would mean the ability to gradually improve your own farming methods.

This game has plenty of fruit trees that will ripen allowing you to pick the fruits right off of them when you can see the fruit. The Orange Season subtitle of the game is no joke, as it seems that oranges are always in season, whereas other fruits will come and go depending on the seasons themselves. You will also often find random fruits and other valuables littering the local nature scape, so you can be pretty sure that you will never go hungry--even though hunger is not a problem for the protagonist in this game. It is for your animals, but all you ever need is sleep. Eating foods will remove your fatigue and restore stamina, but you can also do that just by hitting your pillow anywhere, any time.

Raising animals can be a big part of your farming instead of the traditional style of tilling land, sowing seeds, and watering them until fruition. You can raise chickens, ducks, cows, etc. You can use them as renewable resources and sell the eggs, milk, etc. that are produced. How you ultimately run your farm is up to you, although the game will definitely give you plenty of tasks to keep you more or less having the capability of maintain all styles of farming available within. A point of note is that the hens need a rooster in order to lay viable eggs for hatching. So getting that rooster is going to be important, lest you wish to keep paying $1000 gold for each little chicklet that you purchase. (I have raised 3 chickens from baby chicks so far, all of them egg-laying female. I have no idea if you can get lucky and buy a chick that turns into a rooster. I will probably keep trying, because the rooster was too pricey the first (and only) opportunity I had seen it come on sale.)

Or should you wish, you can opt for a more adventurous career and still maintain a flower garden. The flowers don't need much care, and AFAIK, they will just grow on their own once the seeds are sown. All you need to do is look at them until they are ready to harvest. Flowers can certainly generate a decent income if you have a steady supply of them to sell.

Live as a hermit or social butterfly, or just an animal lover and a people hater? I suppose all of these options are available. And you can practically gift anything to anyone, though if you are looking through your inventory in the pause menu, it does tell you if people will dislike an item. After all, it's right around Christmas time right now, who would want a lump of coal? Building up a relationship takes plenty of time, as the game's relationship hearts look almost infinite wells that will only slowly build up with lots of interactions and plenty of gifts.

When you have enough money and resources through your hard work and scavenging, you will be able to expand your house and fence things inside. I do wish you can just pick up and rearrange your fencing, because I kind of made a couple of mistakes in creating the fence around my chicken coop, and now it looks like a cat walked over my keyboard when I was putting it together. Hmm... That's my story and I will stick to it!

The different seasons will bring different items to plant or find. You will be able to attend the various festivals that occur to participate in the mini-games that are built in in hopes of winning a special prize or two. 

Overall there's just a lot of stuff to do, and so far 8 hours in, I am just scratching at the surface.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
I am playing with a controller, it plays decently well with one. I think there are definitely times when I think a mouse pointer would make things a little smoother, but I prefer the controller here. KB+M of course work perfectly as well.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Pixel-art farming pleasantries. The whole game code is available for people to freely modify it with whatever custom designs should that be a desire.

[h1]Music & Sounds[/h1]
Nothing spectactular, not bad. Mostly just background stuff that you can opt to ignore. I think the dog barks a little too loud, but that's just me probably.

[h1]Audience[/h1]
I think taking one glance at this game, if you have played other similar games, would tell you whether you are the targeted audience.

[h1]Pricing[/h1]
Base price of $13.99 is fair in its Early Access state right now. The price may increase with more content. Currently the Winter Sale price at 30% off is pretty good, in my opinion.

[h1]First-Look Video[/h1]
https://youtu.be/CIpdrjZpgBU

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Fantasy Farming: Orange Season[/i] will offer you plenty of hours of farming simulation goodness with its variety of adaptive styles to the farming idea in that as long as you make money you can keep moving forward with making things bigger and better for yourself. This is clearly a game not for everyone, just like some people think that these farming-sim/RPG style games are just too tedious and too much like real work. To me, I think it's really nice from time to time to sit down with a casual and relaxing game, more or less thoughtless and effortless...

Umm... What do you mean I sat around thoughtless for too long! Wait, did I lose a whole crop of cabbages when I typed this review? NOOOOoooooooo!!!!!

review:
[h1]Esta análise pode ser lida no site [url=https://www.jogosgratisbrasil.com.br/preview-fantasy-farming-orange-season/]Jogos Grátis Brasil[/url][/h1]

[b]Expanda sua fazenda, crie animais e cultive frutos. Seja um bom vizinho, busque um romance, pesque a semana inteira ou ganhe troféus em competições. Aqui você decide o seu futuro.[/b]

Em Fantasy Farming: Orange Season, você é um jovem adulto que sai da casa de seus pais para realizar seu maior sonho: tornar-se um fazendeiro, ou seja, possuir a sua própria terra e viver dos frutos do seu suor.

O primeiro passo para começar nossa aventura está na criação do seu personagem. A customização em si não é muito complexa, pode-se escolher seu gênero, a cor da pele e do cabelo, bem como o seu nome, o nome da sua fazenda e de seu animal de estimação. 

Após a criação de personagem, uma cutscene contando um pouco da história é revelada. Basicamente, com a ajuda de seus pais, você compra o seu primeiro pedaço de terra numa pequena cidade chamada Laranjal. Ao mudar-se, é recebido pela prefeita Julia, que encaminha-o até sua fazenda. Benjamin, o vaqueiro da cidade, dá as boas-vindas com um livro contendo informações básicas para fazendeiros que nada mais é do que um tutorial sobre as mecânicas básicas do jogo.

Com um grande foco em exploração, o título possui diversas áreas desenhadas a mão para conhecer, como: montanhas, lagos, florestas, cavernas e muito mais. O cultivo de produtos em determinada estação do ano, a criação de animais de grande e pequeno porte e a expansão e personalização da sua própria fazenda também são elementos fascinantes de Orange Season.

Contendo mais de 35 tipos de frutas, vegetais e flores, 10 tipos de animais diferentes e inúmeros itens disponíveis, o título cumpre o seu objetivo em evidenciar a vida na fazenda. 

Mas não se engane, é notável que o game não se trata apenas de cuidar da sua fazenda, ele também foca muito no conceito da amizade com a vizinhança. Ao conversar diariamente e cumprir tarefas para seus vizinhos, você obtém pontos de amizade que, conforme aumentam, possibilitam a opção para eventuais romances. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1941668569

Apesar de estar em acesso antecipado desde 2017, o mesmo apresentou melhorias e evoluiu muito nesses últimos dois anos. Agora, em sua versão 0.6, possui muito conteúdo e diversão para oferecer a seus jogadores. A desenvolvedora indie brasileira, Tropical Puppy, está sempre progredindo e se esforça para modelar o jogo com base no feedback da comunidade.

Até agora o título me surpreendeu muito e estou ansiosa para as futuras atualizações que acrescentarão novos elementos para a história, novos diálogos com os vizinhos, sistema de casamento, festivais, áreas inéditas para explorar e com certeza muito mais. O [url=https://tropicalpuppy.com/orange-season-roadmap/]roadmap[/url] está disponível no próprio site da Tropical Puppy onde você pode acompanhar todas as atualizações que serão implementadas no game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198272346711', 'num_games_owned': 156, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1064, 'last_played': 1606438143}
review:
Orange Season has been a delight for a classic farming sim fan such as myself! While the game is still in early access with much more content to come I feel it is already well worth the asking price.

The game offers the usual farming fair we have all come to know and love but what really shines for me is character dialogue. Amazingly, your player character actively takes part in some conversations and cutscenes, and this simple interaction made you feel like your character actually had a soul. Besides that, I felt the townsfolk were all very likable and felt alive compared to the somewhat stale dialogue these sorts of games can fall victim to.  

The only real negative I can think to add was a somewhat less than ideal framerate at times. This combined with the interface could feel a little clunky and slow at times. But this was by no means game-breaking for me. Orange Season hooked me instantly to the tune of 17+ hours at the time of this writing. With many more to come with new updates, I'm sure! 

All in all, I would wholeheartedly recommend this little gem to anyone interested in the genre!

review:
Before you read, this will probably change later. I am not rating it a no because of it being in beta, and yet I am. 
So hear me out, I'm gonna give my pros and then cons and one major con at the end. I will say if you are reading this before purchasing, do not purchase at full price, and I highly suggest taking the price down a notch or two. 

Pros:
I love graphics like this, little indie, little cute, feels like SNES. I do not believe every game needs to be super high tech. 
The animal variety in this game is astonishing thus far, I hope they add more, along with other things to pour your money into.
This games 'mapping' is very big, in my opinion, there is some maze I have yet to even go explore, but only because I heard it was changing constantly because they couldn't decide what to do with the magic forest.
There is some 'strange' creatures in here, I'd love to see more. 
This game has loads of potential for dialogue and adventure if they ever fill it in, but they seem to be focused on surroundings and tools for now. 
Animals have variety of colors and if it pleases you, you may own more than one horse. 
All animals seem to have stats or it's just chickens. I'm not too sure. 
The gathering aspect for chump change is easier than most games, the items on the ground or in the bush is very noticeable, letting you know like "ay psst, want a penny come over here, lass." 
Want to get rich? Fish for the big fishhhh, I just banked off fishing alone and certain crops. 
This game also seems like its going to have cooking, like most other farming games, but the different items to do it with seem exciting thus far.
Naps are good I guess. It's an interesting feature. Brings back stamina and you can nap anywhere. 


Cons: 
Character customization could be really good in this game, maybe even outfits.
When you are on a horse, for some reason running side to side from the screen is faster than going forward or down. I don't know why, me and friends cackled at it when we first noticed.
All npcs are lacking conversation or even development thus far, which is okay, it is still in Beta. 
Animal resource gathering to get it in the bin for the morning is pretty hard, you will most likely either have to choose between gathering crops or stuff from your animal to beat the bin gathering lad. I've never been able to get both, which is okay, but a little weird.
I think the time goes to fast in the game, personally, as stated above, rather pretty quickly the lad comes to get the items from the bin. 
Stamina is way to costly, it makes me not want to do anything besides plant and animals, who cares about upgrades. I'll be rich and happy in my small house at this point. And I get you can nap, but time already goes by so quickly that napping is almost irrelevant to me not unless I run out of stamina before I get home, then I make sure to get back to the second bar and take off. 
Tools were weird, I'm making this a con because I had to google where some of them were. Because, I understand some things need to be found or given, but jeez. 
There is no map.  <--  I want to take it back, there is one it's in the corner up at the very top instead of the menu with other things.
Map for the mines?  Maybe you can earn one later, but they just changed recently along with a several holes being sealed off so, I guess not.
I started playing when you were an allowed a teleport from a witch, and I thought it was SO WICKED, they gave that so early, and it was only helpful with getting home or in town, it wasn't overpowered in my opinion. But they took that way, I was shocked. Because it was such an interesting opening to get that from a witch instantly, a nice witch. So let me compare this to something else, in Stardew Valley the wizard felt like a b**** to befriend and get stuff from and very many other games that involve a 'magical person' are the same way. So I was excited the first one I saw gave me something. 
It's really hard to find npcs and some just lock themselves up in their house. There is something to the north that I just stopped trying to get into or talk to, she just opens the door and in my world (imagination here) sticks out her tongue and shuts it. 
This game is constantly undergoing changes that affect what you already know what to do or how to strive. 

Before my big con, I'd like to say that I wish the social aspect of the game was worked on more rather than the mapping, like forests, mines, lakes, etc. That would at least distract me better to attempt to keep playing it rather than dropping it when something drastically goes array or I get bored because well, stamina problems I have money, but not worth chopping up so much wood to achieve whatever the builder can build.

Major Con, from my end:

I waited about a whole year to buy this game, hoping that the major updates would've already been pressed through. Especially since Stardew Valley lost it's wind after the major fall out they had and now only the creator works on PC, and so far it's only promotions of mods rather than updates. So when I bought this game, I still knew it was in Beta, I just had hoped it would've been developed far long enough that I didn't have to endure 'major' changes that friends warned me might happen in Beta games like this. ( I love farming/social games.) So far I achieved a bunch on my first couple of days along with making loads of money, I still have a ton of money, and I'm still in year one and fall, with my first debt paid off, and I haven't bought extra land (probably will not for a while.)  And the layout of the world is kind of complicated, as there isn't really a map. You kind of have to learn as you go, and that's fine, what isn't fine is areas are constantly changing now. I got used to the mines (took forever) and you need to get 'blue crystals' and the most recent update has taken one mine away and has made what seems to be an elaborate new one from the old one (there was two at one point.) I have no idea where the shroom people are, and I don't care really much to hunt them down at this point. I feel like a lot of hard work to memory was like wiped to a game that should be simple in most aspects. Then because I am in fall, upon the update I received several letters for summer for quests, and that just..really grinds my gears. So the updates when it comes to the world, is kind of hectic, and then put on top of the lack of details quests give, the lack of details with villagers, and other things.  And it makes me not want to play it, I'm not expecting it to be Stardew or Harvest, but I expected the world to be somewhat mostly solid rather than constantly changing. 

Like I said, this probably will change once it finishes. If not I'm terribly sorry for downing such a game that has great potential that it might not ever achieve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198278080248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1427, 'last_played': 1652502434}
review:
An addictive, refreshing, and colorful farming RPG akin to Stardew Valley, Rune Factory, and Harvest Moon. The diversity and character development is impressive and still evolving. With only 23.8 hours, I am still within the first year and can already see how much freedom and choice there is to be made! New areas unfold through mazes and puzzles; some of which harder than others. You actually have to watch your energy and manage your time. It isn't like SDV where you have to make it to bed by a certain hour, you can stay up days on end exploring or working granted that you have enough food on hand. You can save at any point in the game which is a plus, so that you may pick up wherever you left off in the caves or in the forest.

The most profound thing I have noticed that separates the game apart from other farming RPGs is the dialogue and the background stories of characters as they unfold. Their problems, disputes between other characters, and attitudes feel very real. They have depth to them that are charming. I think that's the most interesting part, seeing what the characters think of each other. 

I also enjoy the idea that you can manipulate who ends up with who, or compete in different relationships. This game is very promising and a wonderful collection to your library! Please give Orange Season a chance! You will be smitten with the game and its variety of gameplay mechanics. (You can befriend stray animals like turtles, squirrels, and cats! Please! Do it for them!)

review:
First of all Hudell I want to say good job so far with the game! I have enjoyed the game quite a bit, of course the game is still in development and has ways to go but i for sure can see the potential here and as a person who has been playing farming games since the first HM it is quite an appealing game. 



There are ofc things that I would like to see in the future which I am sure the team behind the game are working hard on such as 



More festivals, Dating or just more day-to-day things etc.



Things I love about the game so far :



- Music is pretty cute 

- The layout of the farm, mountain, village are all pretty good and easy to get around.

- The different animals available is good.

- The seeds available and the farming system it's self is good and simple enough.

- The fishing is pretty neat nice and easy! 

- The foraging items are sweet! Quite a lot of them around which is nice.



Things I don't like so much at this present time: 



The amount of stamina used when using tools even when they have been upgraded I think still uses too much, after clearing a few rocks or branches my stamina is pretty much gone and the amount of stamina available from the foraging items does not really make up for it. I find myself out of stamina really quickly and just going to bed. (hope this can be reduced in the future) :)



- Finding the Big Blue Crystal for the mining quest was super annoying took me almost a month for me to get one even going mining for it everyday, Maybe you can increase the chance of finding one a bit :p 



- There isn't really much to do on a day-to-day basis after attending the farm, animals foraging items around. 

So I normally just go the bed early. 



These are just some of my likes/dislikes of course not everyone will feel the same and I am in no way bashing the game or anything, I do enjoy playing the game considering it is still in development. 



I would give the game 7/10 as it is now :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198007398118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1701903060}
review:
[h1] Lohnt sich im Moment leider noch nicht 	[/h1]


Ich liebe Farmspiele wie Harvest Moon oder auch Stardew Valley, und so musste ich dieses Spiel einfach testen. Besonders das Versprechen eines innovativen Beziehungssystems, bei dem die Dorfbewohner auch untereinander Paare bilden können (was man beeinflussen kann) fand ich sehr anziehend.

Die Story und das Gameplay sind schnell zusammengefasst: schon als Kind hat der/die Protagonist/in den Wunsch, Farmer zu werden. Einmal erwachsen erfüllt er/sie sich diesen Wunsch dann und kauft eine ziemlich heruntergekommene Farm in der Nähe des Städtchens Orange Town. Mit Hilfe der Dorfbewohner macht man sich mit dem Anbau von Gemüse, sowie der Aufzucht von Tieren vertraut, lernt die Stadtbewohner besser kennen und erfüllt Quests für sie, und nimmt an Feiertagen und Events teil. 

Angenehm anders als andere Spiele seiner Art ist dabei die Foraging-Komponente (sprich das Sammeln wilder Früchte und Gegenstände), die im Umland der Stadt zahlreich verteilt sind. Schnell kann man sich so genug Geld für mehr Saatgut und Upgrades zusammensparen. Auch die Ernten bringen ziemlich viel Bares, was den Start angenehm schnell macht.

Leider stellt sich aber schon nach kurzem Eintönigkeit ein, was vor allem auch an den doch noch recht zahlreichen Bugs und fehlenden Inhalten liegt. Bei mir war unter anderem das Ernten der wilden Bäumen verbuggt, so dass keine Früchte mehr nachwachsen. Gleiches galt auch für questrelevante Mineralien in den Minen, die ich trotz täglicher Besuche dort auch nach Wochen nicht vorfinden konnte. Auch die Beziehungen zu den Bewohnern waren anscheinend verbuggt: für manche habe ich lediglich eine Quest erfüllt und direkt einen Freundschaftsstern (=so ähnlich wie Herzen anderer Spiele) erhalten, während ich anderen täglich Geschenke brachte und mehrere Quests erfüllte und sich überhaupt nichts tat.
Die Tagesabläufe der Bewohner waren schwer teilweise schwer nachvollziehbar (z.B. war der lokale Tierexperte, dem man seine Hühner zur Bewertung bringen kann, ständig vom Erdboden verschluckt; eine Dorfbewohnerin stand stundenlang in einer Nische herum und war nicht ansprechbar -> creepy! o.O). 
Auch das Energiesystem ist ziemlich gewöhnungsbedürftig: sind die Felder gegossen, sind bereits ca. 7/8 der Energie futsch und für Angeln oder ähnliches kaum was übrig. Um sie aufzufüllen muss man einerseits ständig etwas essen und andererseits genug schlafen. Die Definition von "genug schlafen" ist aber nicht sehr einsichtig. An manchen Tagen ging ich früh schlafen und wachte am nächsten Morgen trotzdem mit halber Energie auf, an anderen ging ich halb tot kurz vor Mitternacht ins Bett und morgens war alles aufgefüllt. Hm...

Ich weiß, dass das Spiel noch im frühen Early Access ist und ich hoffe (und denke), dass sich hier noch viel tun wird. Derzeit kann ich das Spiel aber leider nicht weiterempfehlen, da (vor allem für den vollen Preis) noch ziemlich wenig im Spiel steckt. Wenn neue Inhalte hinzukommen und Bugs ausgebügelt werden, schaue ich gerne wieder rein und passe diese Review entsprechend an. Aber für den Moment werde ich das Farmer-Dasein erstmal an den Nagel hängen.

review:
Игра - симулятор фермера, казалось бы, ничего нового, очередная "весёлая ферма"; но на удивление разнообразная для инди-проекта. В году реализована сезонность, в каждом из которых геймплей слегка разнится, что не даёт совсем уж заскучать.

Туториал, к сожалению, текстовый, на английском и довольно нудный, так что запросто можно пропустить ключевую информацию - например, я не понял, как продавать что-либо, что фактически делало игру не-играбельной; разработчик подсказал, что надо складывать хлам на продажу в Shipping bin на выходе с фермы. У большинства неписей своё расписание жизни, у кого-то подписанное на табличке, у кого-то нет, что зачастую превращает процесс их поиска в унылый геморрой; надо выучить. Карты нет, в этом большой минус, тоже приходится учить, кто где; но мир небольшой, всё довольно просто.

Кроме фермы, есть несколько других занятий - шахта, рыбалка - так что не обязательно упарываться по посадкам и поливу; но если уж посадил, то будь добр, поливай.

По мере игры появляются новые возможности, открываются новые локации, и т.д. В общем-то, есть чем заняться. Возможно, игра дороговата, но вполне качественно сделана.

Игра пока что на неполный сезон; как только доходите до готовки (cooking), так игру можно и заканчивать - настолько колоссальные финансовые вливания в него, и настолько бредовая реализация.  Разводить брюкву и даже коров к тому моменту уже и так надоедает, и теряется весь челендж игры; зачем всё это, непонятно.
developer_response: продавать предметы, ставить их на [shipping bin]

author: {'steamid': '76561198313836235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 328, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 121, 'last_played': 1564286316}
review:
I've been following this game for quite awhile now, with the promise of characters you can marry off and a solid farming system. It's taken me longer than I'd like, but I finally bought it, and am glad I did! The game is fully playable, with a town filled with characters, mines to explore, and a good amount to do. I'm already addicted to the farming and mining system, and have fallen into the gamer trap of "Just one more day!!!" ...Two hours and three days later, I'm still playing it. The game is still not finished, and right now, that's most evident by the characters. Their dialogue is solid and their characterization very promising, but you can tell they still have a lot more progress to go in giving them full arcs and characterization. However, the developer is very active, and as I can tell from experience, very responsive to the community and sounds like a great person! (Thanks so much for all their hard work! :D :D :D ) 

Pros: (The dev has said there are many more developments to come--I'm especially looking forward to the story and rival marriages--but in the name of fairness, I am only listing the pros available as of this update). 

+ User-interface. I've heard some complaints that the UI is difficult, but I've found it pretty easy, actually. I'm guessing updates have been made, but it took me only a day or so before I learned the controls. The item/tool bars are simple and easily accessible, and you can find everything else you need neatly organized in the one Menu screen.

+ Solid game mechanics. As mentioned before, the game is fully playable, and the farming/mining systems are solid and easily addicting. 

+ Little handholding but good support. The game doesn't bog you down with days' worth of tutorials like in Harvest Moon, but it gives you enough to start with to begin, and the game itself is pretty intuitive if you've played any Harvest Moon games at all. Also, the game is fairly forgiving, since if you tire yourself out, you can just pick fruit around the areas to refill your stamina. This does encourage you to plan ahead, though, so you stock up on food if you're expecting to do a large bulk of work.

+ Balanced. So far, everything from the prices to the stamina to the mining chances seem balanced. If you work hard/long enough, you'll get what you need in a fair amount of time, without it feeling too easy.

+ Great dev! Again, the dev is active and helpful, and has really taken the time to listen to the community to provide a promising game for all those Harvest Moon and Rune Factory fans.

+ Characters. The characters are still in the Early-Access stages, but from what I can tell so far, their dialogue seems pretty solid (if somewhat limited since, again, Early-Access), and they seem to have a lot of potential. I also like how your character actually speaks, instead of just nodding their head with chat bubbles popping above their heads. I can understand if this feature isn't for everyone, but for me, I feel like it gives you more depth, and leads to some humorous moments in the game. If anyone has gone far enough in the mine yet, the dev does have a good sense of humor. 

* Artwork/Music. The artwork is good and gives the game character, and the music is nice to listen to and really sets the peaceful mood you're looking for in a farming game. 



Cons: (Please keep in mind this game is still in Early Access, so I suspect many of these 'cons' will be fixed over the course of the game's development. The fact that there's so few of them I can find is saying something, too). 

- No map (yet!). It took me a bit to get oriented in the game, since the layout in some areas are a bit difficult to navigate (for example, the mine area has a lot of mountains where you have to take staircases to make your way up), but I DID get used to it, and am finding my way alright now. A map would still be helpful for references, though.

- No character portraits (yet). I know this is a very late-stage development for games, so please take that into account, but I do miss not being able to see the characters' portraits. They would really help bring the characters to life, and can tell the player so much about them just from the visuals. 


If you're looking for a finished, polished game, I would suggest holding off on purchasing the game for now, but definitely keep a close eye on it, since it's brimming with potential. However, if you want to support the dev and reward their amazing and much appreciated hard work, then GET THE GAME! It may not be 100% done yet, but it's completely playable and already addicting. I'm looking forward to what else is in the store!
